Abraham Lincoln to William M. Meredith, 9 March 18491 ColE. D. Bakerand myself are the onlyWhigmembers ofCongressfromIllinois– I, of the 30th& he of the 31stWe have reason to think the whigs of thatstatehold us responsible, to some extent, for the appointments which may be made of our

citizens– We do not know you personally; and our efforts to see you have, so far,

been unavailing– I therefore hope I am not obtrusive in saying, in this way, for him

and myself, that when a citizen of Illinois is to be appointed^in yourDepartment^to an office either in or out of the state, wedesire^most respectfully ask^to be heard.2

                  to command appointments from the new Whig presidential administration ofZachary Taylor, for whom he had campaigned and strongly supported in thepresidential election of 1848.Abraham Lincoln to George W.
